etymologies: late 16th century: from Latin privativus ‘denoting privation’, from privat- ‘deprived’ (see privation)

definitions: (of an action or state) marked by the absence, removal, or loss of some quality or attribute that is normally present.
shortDefinitions: (of action or state) marked by absence or loss of some quality or attribute that is normally present

definitions: (of a statement or term) denoting the absence or loss of an attribute or quality

examples.text: the wording of the privative clause

shortDefinitions: (of statement or term) denoting absence or loss of attribute or quality

definitions: (of a particle or affix) expressing absence or negation, for example, the a- (from the alpha privative in Greek), meaning “not,” in atypical.
shortDefinitions: (of particle or affix) expressing absence or negation

definitions: a privative attribute, quality, or proposition.
